lines.text: Sek lain de, tu mainu sek lain de
lines.translation: One more day, you one more day
lines.grammar: This line uses the idiomatic expression "sek lain de" to convey a sense of resignation or acceptance, similar to saying "oh well" in English. The repetition of "one more day" emphasizes the speaker's surrender to fate.

lines.text: Meri haar di ae agg mainu sek lain de x (2)

lines.grammar: The phrase "ae agg" is an idiomatic expression in Punjabi, equivalent to the English phrase "to my heart's content", conveying a sense of satisfaction or pleasure.

lines.text: Dekh lain de, tu mainu dekh lain de
lines.translation: Let me see, you just look at me
lines.grammar: This line employs a common Punjabi idiom "dekh lain de" which translates to "let me see" or "allow me to take a look". The use of the verb "dekh" in the imperative mood and the pronoun "tu" (you) indicates a polite request.

lines.text: Kehde apne te ghair saare dekh lain de x (2)
lines.translation: Where should I look around x (2)
lines.grammar: The phrase "kehde" is an informal way to ask for advice or guidance, equivalent to "what do you think?" or "how about this?", using the first person singular pronoun "mujhe" (me) in a rhetorical sense.

lines.text: Lakh ne buraiyan bande vich hundi aan
lines.translation: Lakh ne badaiyan bande bich hundi aan
lines.grammar: This line uses the present continuous tense to describe an ongoing habit, with "hundi" indicating a habitual action. The phrase "bande vich" is an idiomatic expression meaning "in one's group" or "among friends".

lines.text: Changiyan kise di koyi gaurta hi nai
lines.translation: Changiyan kise di koyi gaurta hi nai
lines.grammar: This line uses the idiomatic expression "hi" to emphasize negation, equivalent to saying "not at all". The sentence is in the present tense and the verb "gaurta" agrees with the subject "koyi", indicating a general or universal truth.

lines.text: Lakh ne kamaiyan bande nu ae hundi aan
lines.translation: Lakhs of unearned people have no money on their hands.
lines.grammar: The verb phrase "ae hundi" is in the present continuous tense, indicating an ongoing situation. The use of "hundi" (having) instead of "hai" (is) emphasizes the lack of money.

lines.text: Rabb mehanat'an de mull khaali molta hi nai
lines.translation: Lord, if you give hard work, it will not just bring you value.
lines.grammar: This line uses the subjunctive mood to express a hypothetical situation, indicating that the speaker is making a suggestion rather than stating a fact. The phrase "mehanat'an" (if you give) also employs an idiomatic construction common in Hindi and Urdu.

lines.text: Dekhi chalde zamane utte zor apne
lines.translation: See, the times are changing
lines.grammar: The verb "dekhi" is in the imperative mood, used to express a sense of urgency or emphasis. The phrase "chalde zamane" is an idiomatic expression meaning "times are changing".

lines.text: Hale samay nu halatan naal khed lain de

lines.text: Sek lain de, tu mainu sek lain de

lines.text: Kehde apne te ghair saare dekh lain de
lines.translation: Where should I look at everything beyond my reach?
lines.grammar: The phrase "kehde" is an informal second-person singular pronoun, equivalent to "you" in English, used to address a close friend or someone familiar. It is often used in casual conversations and adds a sense of informality to the sentence.

lines.text: Dekh lain de, tu mainu dekh lain de
lines.translation: Let me see, you just look at me

lines.text: Kehde apne te ghair saare.
lines.translation: Kehde apne te ghair saare.
lines.grammar: This line uses the idiomatic expression "apne te" to mean "to one's own people", with the verb "kehde" in the imperative mood, instructing someone to go to their own people.

lines.text: Pooja vi karta hoon
lines.translation: I also do puja
lines.grammar: This line illustrates the use of the present continuous tense (vi karta) to express a habitual or regular action, with the verb pooja meaning "to worship" or "to perform puja". The phrase "I also" is an idiomatic translation of the Hindi phrase "pooja vi", emphasizing the speaker's involvement in the activity.

lines.text: Jaap bhi karta hoon
lines.translation: I also chant

lines.text: Kahin devta na ban jaaun

lines.text: Isiliye paap bhi karta hoon
lines.translation: That's why I commit sins too

lines.text: Saukhi chakkni aen unglan de kise hor te
lines.translation: Saukhi chakkni aen unglan de kise hor te
lines.grammar: This sentence uses the informal imperative mood to express a strong suggestion or command, with the verb "de" implying a sense of urgency. The phrase "kise hor te" is an idiomatic expression meaning "to someone else".

lines.text: Kade apni kamiyan te bol ni hunda x (2)

lines.text: Jehde phirde nasihatan dujjeyan nu wadd de
